conclusion: I'll analyze the motion of Car A to determine if the direction of its acceleration changes during the 0-4 second interval.
Car A is represented by the curved line that starts at 0 m/s, increases to 2 m/s at t = 4s.
The curve consists of two identical arcs (as stated in the question).
Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity: Mathematically, acceleration a = dv/dt.
On a v-t graph, acceleration is represented by the slope of the velocity curve.
From t = 0s to t ≈ 2s: The curve slopes upward with decreasing steepness.
At t ≈ 2s: The curve changes from concave down to concave up.
From t ≈ 2s to t = 4s: The curve continues to slope upward with increasing steepness.

premise: The curve slopes upward from t = 0s to t = 4s.
conclusion: Since the slope is always positive (the velocity is always increasing), the acceleration is always positive.
The question asks about the direction of acceleration, not just its sign.

premise: The curve becomes less steep from t = 0s to t ≈ 2s and steeper from t ≈ 2s to t = 4s.
conclusion: The magnitude of acceleration is decreasing from t = 0s to t ≈ 2s and increasing from t ≈ 2s to t = 4s.

premise: The acceleration vector still points in the same direction (forward).
conclusion: This change in magnitude doesn't represent a change in direction.
The second derivative (rate of change of acceleration) can be analyzed.

premise: From t = 0s to t ≈ 2s: The curve is concave down, so d²v/dt² < 0.
From t ≈ 2s to t = 4s: The curve is concave up, so d²v/dt² > 0.
